utterance: I reckon it is so; it does kind of prevent you hearing what you don't want to hear.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: You know well enough what I mean.
speaker: Chet Brooks

utterance: And that ain't all that folks say. They allow that you're doin' a heap too much correspondence with that Californian rough that killed Tom Jeffcourt over there.
speaker: Chet Brooks

utterance: Do they?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Then perhaps they allow that if it was n't for me he would n't be sending a hundred dollars a month to Aunt Martha?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Yes, but they allow he killed Tom for his money. And they do say it's mighty queer doin's in yo' writin' religious letters to him, and Tom your own cousin.
speaker: Chet Brooks

utterance: Oh, they tell those lies here, do they?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: But do they say anything about how, when the same lies were told over in California, the lawyer they've got over there, called Colonel Starbottle, a Southern man too, got up and just wrote to Aunt Martha that she'd better quit that afore she got prosecuted?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: They did n't tell you that, did they, Mister Chester Brooks?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: I don't cotton to what they say, Sally, but you do write to him, and I don't see what you've got to write about you and him. Jule Jeffcourt says that when you got religion at Louisville during the revival, you felt you had a call to write and save sinners, and you did that as your trial and probation, but that since you backslided and are worldly again, and go to parties, you just keep it up for foolin' and flirtin'! She ain't goin' to weaken on the man that shot her brother, just because he's got a gold mine and — a mustache!
speaker: Chet Brooks

utterance: She takes his money all the same.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: She don't,- her mother does. She says if she was a man she'd have blood for blood!
speaker: Chet Brooks

utterance: My!
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: It's a wonder she don't apply to you to act for her.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: If it was my brother he killed, I'd challenge him quick enough.
speaker: Chet Brooks

utterance: Marry her, then, and that'll make you one of the family. I reckon Miss Hilda can bear it.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Look here, Miss Sally, I ain't gifted like you—I ain't on yo' level no how; I can't pass yo' on the road, and so I reckon I must take yo' dust as yo' make it. But there is one thing, Miss Sally, I want to tell you. You know what's going on in this country, you've heard your father say what the opinion of the best men is, and what's likely to happen if the Yanks force that nigger worshiper, Lincoln, on the South. You know that we're drawing the line closer every day, and spottin' the men that ain't sound. Take care, Miss Sally, you ain't sellin' us cheap to some Northern Abolitionist who'd like to set Marm Judy's little niggers to something worse than eavesdropping down there, and mebbe teach 'em to kindle a fire underneath yo' own flo'.
speaker: Chet Brooks

utterance: And let me tell you, Mister Chester Brooks, that it's just such God-forsaken, infant phenomenons as you who want to run the whole country that make all this fuss, when you ain't no more fit to be trusted with matches than Judy's children. What do you know of Mr. Jo Corbin, when you don't even know that he's from Shelbyville, and as good a Suth'ner as you, and if he has n't got niggers it's because they don't use them in his parts?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Yo'r for all the world like one o' Mrs. Johnson's fancy bantams that ain't quit of the shell afore they square off at their own mother. My goodness! Sho! Sho-o-o!
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: I was passing by the post-office at the Cross Roads last week, dear, and I thought of you, and reckoned it was about time that my Pussy got one of her letters from her rich Californian friend- and sure enough there was one. I clean forgot to give it to you then, and only remembered it passing there to-day. I didn't get to see if there was any gold-dust in it, though I suspect that is n't the kind of currency he sends to you.
speaker: Captain Dows

utterance: It is from Mr. Corbin, and only now, paw, I was just thinking that I'd sort of drop writing any more; it makes a good deal of buzzing amongst the neighbors, and I don't see much honey nor comb in it.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Eh, well, child, suit yourself! It's mighty mean, though, for I was just thinking of telling you that Judge Read is an old friend of this Colonel Starbottle, who is your friend's friend and lawyer, and he says that Colonel Starbottle is with us, and working for the cause out there, and has got a list of all the So'thern men in California that are sound and solid for the South. Read says he should n't wonder if he'd make California wheel into line too.
speaker: Captain Dows

utterance: I don't see what that's got to do with Mr. Corbin.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Well, I thought it might interest you, that's all.
speaker: Captain Dows

utterance: Paw thinks that everybody is as keen bent on politics as he is. There's where paw slips up, Jim.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Well, Sally Dows, you here! who'd have thought of seeing you to-day? Why, Chet Brooks allowed that you danced every set last night and did n't get home till daylight. And you you that are going to show up at another party to-night too! Well, I reckon I have n't got that much ambition these times. And out with your new bonnet too.
speaker: Julia Jeffcourt

utterance: If you reckon to tie to everything that Chet Brooks says, you'll want lots of string, and you won't be safe then. You ought to have heard him run on about this one, and that one, and that other one, not an hour ago in our parlor. I had to pack him off, saying he was even making Judy's niggers tired.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: I suppose there's no news up at yo' house either? Everything's going on as usual — and — you get yo' California draft regularly?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: I wish, cousin Sally, you'd just let up talking to me about that money. You know as well as I do that I allowed to maw I wouldn't take a cent of it from the first! I might have had all the gowns and bonnets
speaker: Julia Jeffcourt

utterance: I wanted from her; she even offered to take me to St. Louis for a rig-out if I'd been willing to take blood money. But I'd rather stick to this old sleazy mou'nin' for Tom
speaker: Julia Jeffcourt

utterance: than flaunt round in white muslins and China silks at ten dollars a yard, paid for by his murderer.
speaker: Julia Jeffcourt

utterance: You know black's yo' color always, taking in your height and complexion, Jule.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: But you can't keep up this gait always. You know some day you might come upon this Mr. Corbin.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: He'd better not cross my path.
speaker: Julia Jeffcourt

utterance: I've heard girls talk like that about a man and then get just green and yellow after him.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: But goodness me! speaking of meeting people reminds me I clean forgot to stop at the stage office and see about bringing over the new overseer. Lucky I met you, Jule! Good-by, dear. Come in to-night, and we'll all go to the party together.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: You 're always on hand yourself at Kirby station when the kyars come in to bring passengers to Pineville, Mr. Sledge?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Yes, Miss.
speaker: Mr. Sledge

utterance: Yo' haven't brought any strangers over lately?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Well, last week Squire Farnham of Green Ridge-if he kin be called a strangeras used to live in the very house yo' father
speaker: Mr. Sledge

utterance: Yes, I know, but if an entire stranger comes to take a seat for Pineville, you ask him if that's his name, and give it to him if it is. And And Mr. Sledgeit's nobody's business but-yours and mine.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: I understand, Miss Sally, with a slow, paternal, tolerating wink. He'll get it, and nobody else, sure.
speaker: Mr. Sledge

utterance: Thank you; I hope Mrs. Sledge is getting round again.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Pow'fully, Miss Sally.
speaker: Mr. Sledge

utterance: Dey is a gemplum, Miss Sally.
speaker: Mammy Judy's children

utterance: Yes, yes, I'll be there in a minute. He can wait. Run away.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: And he said I was to guv yo' dis yer.
speaker: Mammy Judy's children

utterance: For Heaven's sake, did n't you get my note at the station telling you not to come?
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: No, I did n't go to no station. I walked here all the way from Shelbyville. I thought it might seem more like the square thing to her for me to do. I sent him by express ahead in the box. It's been at the stage office all day.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: But you must go yes - go now, at once! Don't talk now, but go.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: I did n't come here to interfere with things I did n't kalkilate to see, and that I ain't in touch with,but to know if you think I'd better bring him or —
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: Go. You must not be known here.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Interduce me.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: Miss Jeffcourt.
speaker: Miss Sally

utterance: Yer don't say my name. Tell her I'm Joseph Corbin of 'Frisco, California, who killed her brother. I came here to try and fix things again and I've brought him.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: Are you men! who stand here with the man before you that killed my brother, and see him offer me his filthy villainous hand- and dare not strike him down!
speaker: Julia Jeffcourt

utterance: She's right, gentlemen. She's right. It might have been otherwise. I might have allowed that it might be otherwise, but she's right. I'm a Soth'n man myself, gentlemen, and I reckon to understand what she has done. I killed the only man that had a right to stand up for her, and she has now to stand up for herself. But if she wants and you see she allows pass that on to some of you, or all of you, I'm willing. As many as you like, and in what way you like I waive any chyce of weapon -I'm ready, gentlemen. I came here with him for she wants to that purpose.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: I've got him in a box at the stage office. I had him dug up that I might bring him here, and mebbe bury some of the trouble and difference along with his friends. It might be, it might be from the way things are piling up on me that some one might have rung in another corpse instead o' him, but so far as I can judge, allowin' for the space of time and nat❜ral wear and tear-it's him!
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: Whatever ye make up your mind to do about me, I reckon ye'd better do it after the funeral. I'm always ready. But he, what with being in a box and changing climate, had better go first.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: for reasons.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: of that famous son of the South, Colonel Starbottle,
speaker: Judge Reed

utterance: But she spat in your face,
speaker: Sally Dows

utterance: That's so, but I reckoned you said something in one of your letters about turning the other cheek when you were smitten. Of course, as you don't believe it now, I suppose that's been played on me, too.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance:
Look here, Mr. Joseph Jeremiah Corbin, if instead of cavortin' round on yo'
knees trying to conciliate an old woman who never had a stroke of luck till you killed her son, and a young girl who won't be above letting on afore you think it that your conciliatin' her means sparkin' her; if instead of that foolishness you'd turn your hand to trying to conciliate the folks here and keep 'em from going into that fool's act of breaking up these United States; if instead of digging up second-hand corpses that's already been put out of sight once you'd set to work to try and prevent the folks about here from digging up their old cranks and their old whims, and their old women fancies, you'd be doing something like a Christian and a man! What's yo'
blood-guiltiness - I'd like to know-alongside of the blood-guiltiness of those fools who are just wild to rush into it, led by such turkey - cocks as yo' friend Colonel Starbottle? And you 've been five years in California a free State and that's all yo' 've toted out of it - a dead body! There now, don't sit there and swing yo' hat under that chyar, but rouse out and come along with me to the pawty if you can shake a foot, and show Miss Pinkney and the gyrls yo' fit for something mo' than to skirmish round as a black japanned spittoon for Julia Jeffcourt!
speaker: Sally Dows

utterance: Marse Linkum
speaker: Mammy Judy

utterance: The Souf,
speaker: Mammy Judy

utterance: Joseph Corbin,
speaker: Sally Dows

utterance: They are coming through the woods. Run, or you'll be taken. Why do you linger?
speaker: Sally Dows

utterance: You know why,
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: Yes, but you have done yo' duty. You have done his work. The task is finished now, and yo' free.
speaker: Sally Dows

utterance:
Joseph, fly and take me with you. For I was wrong, and I want you to forgive me. I knew your heart was not in this, and I ought not to have asked you. Joseph-listen!
I never wanted to avenge myself nor him when I spat on your face. I wanted to avenge myself on her. I hated her, because I thought she wanted to work upon you and use you for herself.
speaker: Sally Dows

utterance: Your mother,
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: No, you know who I mean Miss Sally.
speaker: Sally Dows

utterance: They are coming. You must go. This is no place for you. Stop! it's too late; you cannot go now until they have passed. Come here- crouch down here over this grave SO.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: They were the vedettes, but they have fallen back on the main skirmish line and will be here in force in a moment. Go while you can.
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: It was with his own pistol too,
speaker: Jo Corbin

utterance: Come down from there, Johnny Reb, I want to speak to you,
speaker: the young corporal

utterance: It's time to go home, Johnny.
speaker: the young corporal

utterance: It's agin the rules, boys, for any but her to touch it,
speaker: a bystander

utterance: Guv'ment oughter have more sense than to make a woman pick mail-bags outer the road,
speaker: Jo Simmons

utterance: Tain't in her day's work anyhow; Guv'ment oughter hand 'em over to her like a lady; it's rich enough and ugly enough.
speaker: Jo Simmons

utterance: Tain't Guv'ment; it's that stage company's airs and graces, They think it mighty fine to go beltin' by, makin' everybody take their dust, just because stoppin' ain't in their contract. Why, if that expressman who chucked down the bag had any feelin's for a lady
speaker: a newcomer

utterance:
Guess you don't know much o' that expressman's feelin's, stranger, Why, you oughter see him just nussin' that bag like a baby as he comes tearin' down the grade, and then rise up and sorter heave it to Mrs. Baker ez if it was a five-dollar bokay! His feelin's for her!
Why, he's give himself so dead away to her that we're looking for him to forget what he's doin' next, and just come sailin' down hisself at her feet.
speaker: Jo Simmons

utterance: Foolishness.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Good-morning, Mrs. Baker, I'm Harry Home, of San Francisco.
speaker: Harry Home

utterance:
How dare you touch it! How dare you come in here!
Who are you, anyway? Go outside, at once!
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: I'm afraid you don't know me, after all! I'm Harry Home, the Department Agent from the San Francisco office. My note of advice, No. 201, with my name on the envelope, seems to have miscarried too.
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: As far as you knew, I had no business to go near it. Glad to see you know how to defend Uncle Sam's property so well. I was only a bit puzzled to know if that thing was on the bag when it was delivered to you ?
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: It's only the expressman's foolishness, He thinks it smart to tie some nonsense on that bag with the wire when he flings it down.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: As long as he does n't. meddle with the inside of the bag, I suppose you must put up with it,
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: But enough of this. Now, Mrs. Baker, to come to my business here. Briefly, then, it does n't concern you in the least, except so far as it may relieve you and some others, whom the Department knows equally well, from a certain responsibility, and, perhaps, anxiety. We are pretty well posted down there in all that concerns Laurel Run, and I think we 've known all about you and John Baker. My only business here is to take your place to-night in receiving the "Omnibus Way Bag," that you know arrives here at 9.30, does n't it?
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: Yes, sir, but it never has anything for us, except
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: except a notification from Hickory Hill post-office. It leaves there, at half past eight exactly, and it's about an hour's run seven miles by road.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Exactly,
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: Well, 1 will receive the bag, open it, and dispatch it again. You can, if you choose, take a holiday.
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: But, there are the people who come for letters, you know.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: I thought you said there were no letters at that time,
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: No-but-but the boys come all the same.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Oh!
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: Now, I should like to refer an instant to my first communication to you. Have you got it handy?
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: No; I sent it over to Mr. Green, of Hickory Hill, for information.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: What!
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: And what did he say?
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: Nothing; he did n't return them.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Naturally,
speaker: Harry Home

utterance:
You oblige me, Mrs. Baker, to speak more frankly to you than I had intended.
You have unwittingly, I believe — given information to a man whom the Government suspects of peculation. You have, without knowing it, warned the postmaster at Hickory Hill that he is suspected; and, as you might have frustrated our plans for tracing a series of embezzlements to their proper source, you will see that you might have also done great wrong to yourself as his only neighbor and the next responsible person.
In plain words, we have traced the disappearance of money letters to a point when it lies between these two offices. Now, I have not the least hesitation in telling you that we do not suspect Laurel Run, and never have suspected it. Even the result of your thoughtless act, although it warned him, confirms our suspicion of his guilt.
As to the warning, it has failed, or he has grown reckless, for another letter has been missed since. To-night, however, will settle all doubt in the matter. When I open that bag in this office to-night, and do not find a certain decoy letter in it, which was last checked at Heavy Tree Crossing, I shall know that it remains in Green's possession at Hickory Hill.
speaker: the Department Agent

utterance:
Come, Mrs.
Baker, don't let this worry you. As I told you at first, you have nothing to fear. Even your thoughtlessness and ignorance of rules have contributed to show your own innocence.
Nobody will ever be the wiser for this; we do not advertise our affairs in the Department. Not a soul but yourself knows the real cause of my visit here. I will leave you here alone for a while, so as to divert any suspicion. You will come, as usual, this evening, and be seen by your friends; I will only be here when the bag arrives, to open it. Good-by, Mrs. Baker; it's a nasty bit of business, but it's all in the day's work.
I've seen worse, and, thank God, you're out of it.
speaker: the Department Agent

utterance: Where is the through money letter that came in that bag?
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: What do ― you mean?
speaker: Stanton Green

utterance: I mean that it's a decoy, checked at Heavy Tree Crossing, and that Mr. Home, of San Francisco, is now waiting at my office to know if you have taken it!
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Good God! you've opened it already!
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Yes! I was owing some bills the col-lector was waiting here for the money, and I took something from the packet. But I was going to make it up by next mail — I swear it.
speaker: Stanton Green

utterance: How much have you taken?
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Only a trifle. I-
speaker: Stanton Green

utterance: How much?
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: A hundred dollars!
speaker: Stanton Green

utterance: No; as long as the money is found in the bag the package may have been broken accidentally. Now burst open one or two of those other packages a little-so;
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Send for the expressman, and keep yourself out of the way for a moment
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Mrs. Baker!
speaker: the expressman

utterance:
There's a big San Francisco swell takin'
my place at Laurel to-night, Charley.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: the expressman

utterance: And it's a pity that the Omnibus Way Bag happened to get such a shaking up and banging round already, coming here.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Eh?
speaker: the expressman

utterance: I say, that it would be just awful if that keerful city clerk found things kinder mixed up inside when he comes to open it. I would n't give him trouble for the world, Charley.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: No, ma'am, it ain't like you.
speaker: the expressman

utterance: So you'll be particularly careful on my account.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Mrs. Baker, if that bag should tumble off a dozen times between this and Laurel Hill, I'll hop down and pick it up myself.
speaker: the expressman

utterance: Thank you! shake!
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance:
And you ain't going down with us, Mrs.
Baker?
speaker: the expressman

utterance: Of course not; it would n't do, for I ain't here, don't you see?
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Of course!
speaker: the expressman

utterance:
Don't move, but listen to me, for God's sake!
I am ruined, I know, even though you have just saved me from detection and disgrace.
I have been mad! - a fool, to do what I have done, I know, but you do not know all — you do not know why I did it - you cannot think of the temptation that has driven me to it. Listen, Mrs. Baker. I have been striving to get money, honestly, dishonestly
-any way, to look well in your eyes-to make myself worthy of you to make myself rich, and to be able to offer you a home and take you away from Laurel Run. It was all for you, it was all for love of you, Betsy, my darling. Listen to me!
speaker: Stanton Green

utterance: Leave me be, looney, or I'll scream!
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance:
What did you come riding over here for, then? What did you take all this risk for?
Why did you rush over here to share my disgrace for you are as much mixed up with
--you this now as I am if did n't calculate to share everything else with me? What did you come here for, then, if not for me?
speaker: Stanton Green

utterance:
What did I come here for? Well! -I came here for John Baker's sake! John Baker, who stood between you and death at Burnt Ridge, as I stand between you and damnation at Laurel Run, Mr. Green! Yes, John Baker, lying under half of Burnt Ridge, but more to me this day than any living man crawling over it-in-in - oh, fatal climax!in a month o' Sundays!
What did I come here for? I came here as John Baker's livin' wife to carry on dead John Baker's work. Yes, dirty work this time, may be, Mr. Green! but his work and for him only-precious! That's what I came here for; that's what I live for; that's what I'm waiting for- to be up to him and his work always! That's me- Betsy Baker!
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Stanton Green, don't be a fool! Rise up out of this, and be a man again. Take enough out o' that bag to pay what you owe Gov'ment, send in your resignation, and keep the rest to start you in an honest life elsewhere. But light out o' Hickory Hill afore this time to-morrow.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: You are going?
speaker: Stanton Green

utterance: Yes. Either she could not hold seriousness long in her capricious little fancy, or, with feminine tact, she sought to make the parting less difficult for him, for she broke into a dazzling smile. Yes, I'm goin' to run Blue Lightning agin Charley and that way bag back to Laurel Run, and break the record.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance:
You'll have to ballast your next way bag, boss, or you 'll have to make a new contract with the company.
We've lost ten minutes in five miles over that bucking thing.
speaker: the expressman

utterance: It's all right, Mrs. Baker. He's safe this time.
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: I'm so glad!
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: So am I, for, from all I have gathered this afternoon, it seems he was an old pioneer of Laurel Run, a friend of your husband's, and, I think, more fool than knave!
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: Did he get quite away, Mrs. Baker?
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: I'm sure I don't know what you're talking about. I don't see why I should know anything about it, or why he should go away at all.
speaker: Mrs. Baker

utterance: Well, you see, it might have occurred to his friends that the coins were marked! That is, no doubt, the reason why he would take their good advice and go. But, as I said before, Mrs. Baker, you're all right, whatever happens, the Government stands by you!
speaker: Harry Home

utterance: Ye kin put some things in my carpet bag agin the time the sled comes round.
speaker: Hays

utterance: Then you're not coming back tonight? What's goin' on at the summit, father?
speaker: Zuleika

utterance: I am. You don't reckon I kalkilate to stop thar I'm going on as far as Horseley's to close up that contract afore the weather changes.
speaker: Hays

utterance: I kinder allowed it was funny you 'd go to the hotel to-night. There's a dance there; those two Wetherbee girls and Mamie Harris passed up the road an hour ago on a wood-sled, nigh blown to pieces and sittin' up in the snow like skeert white rabbits.
speaker: Zuleika

utterance: Let 'em go. Let 'em go for all the good their foolparents will ever get outer them, or the herd of wayside cattle they 've let them loose among.
speaker: Hays

utterance: I reckon they haven't much to do at home, or are hard put for company, to travel six miles in the snow to show off their prinkin' to a lot of idle louts shiny with bear's grease and scented up with doctor's stuff,
speaker: Zuleika

utterance:
Never you mind, Zuly. When your brother Jack comes home he 'll know what's what, and have all the proper New York ways and style. It's nigh on three years now that he's had the best training Dr.
Dawson's Academy could give,—sayin' nothing of the pow ful Christian example of one of the best preachers in the States. They may n't have worldly, ungodly fandangoes where he is, and riotous livin', and scarlet abominations, but I've been told that they've 'tea circles, and assemblies,' and 'harmony concerts' of young folks and dancin'
yes, fine square dancin' under control. No, I ain't stinted him in anythin'. You kin remember that, Zuleika, when you hear any more gossip and backbitin' about your father's meanness. I ain't spared no money for him.
speaker: Hays

utterance: I reckon not. Why, there's that draft fur two hundred and fifty dollars that kem only last week from the Doctor's fur extras.
speaker: Zuleika

utterance: Yes, the Doctor mout hev writ more particklers, but parsons ain't allus business men. I reckon these here extrys were to push Jack along in the term, as the Doctor knew I wanted him back here in the spring, now that his brother has got to be too stiff-necked and self-opinionated to do his father's work.
speaker: Hays

utterance: You'd better find out first how all the schoolin' and trainin' of Jack's is goin' to jibe with the Ranch, and if he ain't been eddicated out of all knowledge of station business or keer for it. New York ain't Hays' Ranch, and these yer assemblies' and ' harmony' doin's and their airs and graces may put him out of conceit with our plain ways. I reckon ye did n't take that to mind when you've been hustlin' round payin' two hundred and fifty dollar drafts for Jack and 117 quo'llin' with Bijah! I ain't sayin' nothin', father, only mebbe if Bijah had had drafts and extrys flourished around him a little more, mebbe he'd have been more polite and not so rough spoken. Mebbe, even I'd be a little more in the style to suit Master Jack when he comes ef I had three hundred dollars' worth of convent schoolin' like Mamie Harris.
speaker: Zuleika

utterance: Yes, and you'd have only made yourself fair game for ev'ry schemin', lazy sport or counter-jumper along the road from this to Sacramento!

utterance:
I reckon you won't be wantin' any supper before you go?

utterance: Look here, one of two things has got to happen: either we must change our restaurant or I'm going to resign.
speaker: Joe Tallant

utterance: Why?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Well, to make matters clear, I'm obliged 219 to tell you something that in our business. we usually keep a secret. About three weeks ago I had a notice to transfer twenty feet of Gold Hill to a fellow named Tournelli.' Well, Tournelli happened to call for it himself, and who the devil do you suppose Tournelli was? Why our Italian waiter. I was regularly startled, and so was he. But business is business; so I passed him over the stock and said nothing- nor did he-neither there nor here. Day before yesterday he had thirty feet more transferred to him, and sold out.
speaker: Joe Tallant

utterance: Well?
speaker: narrator

utterance: Well
speaker: Joe Tallant

utterance: Gold Hill's worth six hundred dollars a foot. That's eighteen thousand dollars cash. And a man who's good enough for that much money is too good to wait upon me. Fancy a man who could pay my whole year's salary with five feet of stock slinging hash to me. Fancy you tipping him with a quarter!
speaker: Joe Tallant

utterance: But if he don't mind it and prefers to continue a waiter-why should you care? And we 're not supposed to know.
speaker: narrator

utterance: That's just it.
speaker: Joe Tallant

utterance: That's just where the sell comes in. Think how he must chuckle over us! No, sir! There's nothing aristocratic about me; but, by thunder, if I can't eat my dinner, and feel I am as good as the man who waits on me, I'll resign from the Club.
speaker: Joe Tallant

utterance: Hi, waiter-you, Tournelli.

utterance: He may buy up enough stock to control the board and dismiss me; but, by thunder, if it costs me my place, I'm going to have some more chicken!

speaker: Tom

utterance: I don't know what he meant; but since he chooses to talk of his own affairs publicly, I don't mind saying that they are neither very weighty nor very dangerous. It's only the old story: the usual matrimonial infidelities that are mixed up with the Californian emigration. He leaves the regular wife behind, fairly or unfairly, I can't say. She gets tired waiting, after the usual style, and elopes with somebody else. The Western Penelope is n't built for waiting. But she seems to have converted some of his property into cash when she skipped from St. Louis, and that's where his chief concern comes in. That's what he wanted to see me for; that's why he inveigled me into that infernal pantry of his one day to show me a plan of his property, as if that was any good.
speaker: Jack Manners

utterance: Then you did n't do any thing for him—give him any advice, eh?
speaker: the Quartermaster

utterance: No; for the property 's as much hers as his, and he has n't got a divorce; and, as it's doubtful whether he did n't desert her first, he can't get one. He was surprised when I told him that he was obliged to support her, and was even liable for her debts. But people who are always talking of invoking the law know nothing about it.
speaker: Jack Manners

utterance: Then you did n't give him any points about shooting?
speaker: the Quartermaster

utterance: No; he does n't even know the man she went off with. It was eighteen months ago, and I don't believe he'd even know her again if he met her. But, if he is n't much of a client, we shall miss him to-night as a waiter, for the place is getting full, and there are not enough to serve.
speaker: Jack Manners

At least that was the explanation given by Hays, for the woman had fainted and been driven off to her hotel by the Quartermaster, and Tournelli had escaped. But the Editor was on his track.

utterance:
Look here," he said abruptly, "I have passed my word to the crowd yonder that you are a dead-broke miner called Fowler.
I allowed that you might have had some row with that Sydney duck, Australian Pete, in the mines. That satisfied them. If I go back now, and say it's a lie, that your name ain't Fowler, and you never knew who Pete was, they'll jest pass you over to the police to deal with you, and wash their hands of it altogether. You may prove to the police who you are, and how that d- — clerk mistook you, but it will give you trouble. And who is there here who knows who you really are?
speaker: Tom Flynn

utterance: No one
speaker: Harry Flint

utterance: And you say you're an orphan, and ain't got any relations livin' that you 're beholden to?
speaker: Tom Flynn

utterance: No one.
speaker: Harry Flint

utterance: Then, take my advice, and be Fowler, and stick to it! Be Fowler until Fowler turns up, and thanks you for it; for you 've saved Fowler's life, as Pete would never have funked and lost his grit over Fowler as he did with you; and you've a right to his name.
speaker: Tom Flynn

utterance:
Don't you see what all that means?
You 're in the biggest streak of luck a man ever had. You've got the cards in your own hand! They spell "Fowler"! Play Fowler first, last, and all the time. Good-night, and good luck, Mr.
Fowler.

A friend's.

utterance:
You are bearing my brother's name.
But it was a name that the unhappy boy had so shamefully disgraced in Australia that he abandoned it, and, as he lay upon his death-bed, the last act of his wasted life was to write an imploring letter begging me to change mine too. For the infamous companion of his crime who had first tempted, then betrayed him, had possession of all his papers and letters, many of them from me, and was threatening to bring them to our Virginia home and expose him to our neighbors. Maddened by desperation, the miserable boy twice attempted the life of the scoundrel, and might have added that 267 blood guiltiness to his other sins had he lived. I did change my name to my mother's maiden one, left the country, and have lived here to escape the revelations of that desperado, should he fulfill his threat.
speaker: the young lady in mourning

utterance: Thank God! you are forever safe from any exposure from that man," he said, gravely, "and the name of Fowler has never been known in San Francisco save in all respect and honor. It is for you to take back-fearlessly and alone!

speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
It's a year since there was a Chinaman chased by some Irishmen from the Crossing into the brush about yer, and he was too afeered to come out, and nigh most starved to death in thar. I had to drag him out and start him on the mountain, for you couldn't get him back to the road.
He was the last one but you.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Do you reckon it's the right thing for a girl like you to run about with trash of this kind, and mix herself up with all sorts of rough and bad company?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Look! if you're goin' to talk like Dad, I'll go back.
speaker: Flip

utterance: That is why, then, you take so much stock in tramps. You expect to recognize him?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Well, there is suthing in that, and there's suthing in this: some o' these chaps might run across brother and do him a good turn for the sake of me.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Like me, for instance?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
Like you.
You'd do him a good turn, wouldn't you?
speaker: Flip

utterance: You bet!
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: only don't you go to throwing yourself round promiscuously.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: No, no one ever did. It shows, I had done 'em good, and they could get on alone. Don't it?
speaker: Flip

utterance: It does.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Have you any other friends that come?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Only the Postmaster at the Crossing.
speaker: Flip

utterance: The Postmaster?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Yes; he's reckonin' to marry me next year, if I'm big enough.
speaker: Flip

utterance: And what do you reckon?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: That's telling.
speaker: Flip

utterance:
ther's your trail. It gets plainer and broader the further you get on, but you must use your eyes here, and get to know it well afore you get into the fog.
Good-by.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Good-by.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: You've got something for me.
speaker: Flip

utterance: They're paid for.
speaker: Flip

utterance: That's so,
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: but I thought ez it's a valooable package, maybe ye might want to examine it to see that it was all right afore ye receipted for it.
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: I'll risk it, and if it ain't right I'll let ye know.
speaker: Flip

utterance: We ain't had the pleasure of seeing you down at the Crossing for a month o' Sundays.
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: Some folks let on you was keepin' company with some feller like Bijah Brown, and you were getting a little too set up for the Crossing.
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: Then I allowed how ez you might have company. I reckon there's some city folks up at the summit. I saw a mighty smart, fash'n'ble gal cavorting round. Hed no end o' style and fancy fixin's. That's my kind, I tell you. I just weaken on that sort o' gal,
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: Strange I ain't got to see her yet.
speaker: Flip

utterance: But you might get to see her at the edge of the Gin and Ginger Woods, if you'll take a pasear there with me.
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: Fine doin's this, yer receivin' clandecent bundles and letters, eh?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Sit down, can't ye? Don't you see you're a witness?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Witness,
speaker: Flip

utterance: Yes, a witness! He gave ye letters and bundles.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Weren't they directed to me?
speaker: Flip

utterance: Yes, in course, yes.
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: Do you lay claim to them?
speaker: Flip

utterance: No.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Do you?
speaker: Flip

utterance: No.
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: Then, if you're not claimin' 'em for yourself, and you hear father say they ain't his, I reckon the less you have to say about 'em the better.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Thar's suthin' in that.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Then why don't she say who sent 'em, and what they are like, if there's nothin' in it?
speaker: the Postmaster at Fisher's Crossing

utterance: Yes, Flip, why don't you?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Maybe you forget how you used to row and tear round here because tramps and such like came to the ranch for suthin', and I gave it to 'em? Maybe you'll quit tearin' round and letting yourself be made a fool of now by that man, just because one of those tramps gets up and sends us some presents back in turn?
speaker: Flip

utterance:
'Twasn't me, Flip, Twasn't my doin'.
I allus said if you cast your bread on the waters it would come back to you by return mail. The fact is, the Gov'ment is gettin' too high-handed! Some o' these bloated officials had better climb down before next leckshen.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance:
Maybe, ye'd better find out whether one of those officials comes up to this yer ranch to steal away a gal about my own size, or to get points about diamond-making.
I reckon he don't travel round to find out who writes all the letters that go through the Post Office.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Ye didn't none on ye happen to drop anything round yer last night?
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: I dropped a pocketbook containing government bonds and some other securities, with between fifty and sixty thousand dollars, but no matter, if any man will return a few autograph letters from foreign potentates that happened to be in it,-of 381 no value to anybody but the owner,-he can keep the money. Thar's nothin' mean about me.
speaker: Peter Drummond

utterance: But hev you?
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: I lost my pile to Jack Hamlin at drawpoker, over at Wingdam last night, but I don't calkilate to find it lying round loose.
speaker: another

utterance: Ef I was you, I wouldn't flourish that yer ring around much afore folks. I've seen better men nor you strung up a tree by Vigilantés for having even less than that in their possession.
speaker: Peter Drummond

utterance: And I wouldn't say much about bein' up so d-d early this morning, it might look bad before a jury.
speaker: an even more pessimistic comrade

utterance: I'm dog-goned, ef I don't believe that Cass is looney over that yer ring he found. Wears it on a string under his shirt.
speaker: one commentator

utterance: Oh, come here, please do; quick!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I heard some one coming through the bushes, and I waited. Come quick. It's something too awful for anything.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: It was just here, just here that I went into the bush and cut a switch for my mare,and, just here, look, see! this is what I found.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: But you're not looking the right way, look there!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Ain't he horrid ? but what killed him?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Turn him over again, May be you'll find another wound.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Perhaps you'd better ride on, Miss, afore you get summoned as a witness. I'll give warning at Red Chief's Crossing, and send the coroner down here.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Let me go with you, it would be such fun. I don't mind being a witness. Or, I'll wait here till you come back.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: But you see, Miss, it wouldn't seem right-
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: But I found him first
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Who is the coroner ?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Joe Hornsby.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: The tall, lame man, who was half eaten by a grizzly?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Well, look now! I'll ride on and bring him back in half an hour. There!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: But, Miss-!
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Oh, don't mind me. I never saw anything of this kind before, and I want to see it all.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Do you know Hornsby ?
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: No, but I'll bring him.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Have you been long in these parts, Miss?
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: About two weeks. Good-by, just now. Look around for the pistol or anything else you can find, although I have been over the whole ground twice already.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Here's something! It dropped from the bosom of his shirt on the ground. Look!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Shall I open it?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance: It's a little ring looks like an engagement ring. Something is written on it. Look! May to Cass.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: It's mine, mine! I dropped it. It's nothing-nothing, a mere trifle. I'll take it.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Not much.
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance: But it's mine. I found it six months ago in the road. I-picked it up.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: With your name already written on it! How handy!
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance: It's an old story All Blazing Star knows I found it.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Then ye'll have no difficulty in provin' it, Just now, however, we've found it, and we propose to keep it for the inquest.
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance: It was a fair fight, and was settled by the man az was peartest and liveliest with his weapon. We had a sort of unpleasantness over at Lagrange the night afore, along of our both hevin' a monotony of four aces. We had a clinch and a stamp around, and when we was separated it was only a question of shootin' on sight. He left Lagrange at sun up the next morning, and I struck across a bit o' buckeye and underbrush and came upon him, accidental like, on the Red Chief Road. I drawed when I sighted him, and called out. He slipped from his mare and covered himself with her flanks, reaching for his holster, but she rared and backed down on him across the road and into the grass, where I got in another shot and fetched him.
speaker: Kanaka Joe

utterance: And you stole his mare?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: I got away.
speaker: Kanaka Joe

utterance: I came here to refresh my memory, as Mr. Hornsby thought I might be asked to give my evidence again at Blazing Star.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: And you?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I stumbled upon the place just now while prospecting, or I shouldn't be here.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Then it was you made these holes?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: No, Nobody but a stranger would go foolin' round such a spot.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: I mean-no one would dig here.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Do you mean to say that every miner doesn't know that it's lucky to dig wherever human blood has been spilt ?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I never heard it before.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: And you call yourself a California miner?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I do.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: You certainly do not seem like most of the miners I have met.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Nor you like any girl from the East I ever met.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: What do you mean?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: What I say.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Tell us, Joe, Let it out and we'll make it easy for you.
speaker: a sympathetic and laughter-loving juror

utterance: Prisoner, remember that your life is in peril. Do you refuse ?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Well, as I reckon I'm not up yer for stealin' a ring that another man lets on to have found, and as fur as I kin see, hez nothin' to do with the case, I do!
speaker: Kanaka Joe

utterance: Thank you, but I insist upon getting down.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: If the lady wants to ride inside, let her.
speaker: the driver

utterance: Just a minit, Miss, ye don't onderstand me. I only-
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance: Do you, Do you want this man inside?
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: No!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Here! Somebody take my lines.
speaker: Mountain Charley

utterance: You're riding inside?
speaker: Mountain Charley

utterance: He is!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: And you? onless you're kalkilatin' to take a little 'pasear' you're booked outside. Get up.
speaker: Mountain Charley

utterance: What a brute he was, ugh!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Who? Oh, yes! I see!
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: I suppose I ought to thank you, but you know, really, I could have kept him out if you hadn't pulled his wrist from outside. I'll show you. Look! Put your hand on the handle there! Now, I'll hold the lock inside firmly. You see, you can't turn the catch!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I hope you're not flustered, Miss, by the-by the
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: I? Oh, dear, no!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: One meets all sorts of folks traveling.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: I dare say. I don't know. I never before met any one who was rude to me. I have traveled all over the country alone, and with all kinds of people ever since I was so high. I have always gone my own way, without hindrance or trouble. I always do. I don't see why I shouldn't. Perhaps other people mayn't like it. I do. I like excitement. I like to see all that there is to see. Because I'm a girl I don't see why I cannot go out without a keeper, and why I cannot do what any man can do that isn't wrong, do you? Perhaps you do perhaps you don't. Perhaps you like a girl to be always in the house dawdling or thumping a piano or reading novels. Perhaps you think I'm bold because I don't like it, and won't lie and say I do.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: You know you were shocked when I went to fetch that Hornsby, the coroner, after we found the dead body.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Hornsby wasn't shocked.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: What do you mean?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: You were good friends enough until-
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Until he insulted me just now, is that it ?
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Until he thought, that because you were-you know-not so-so-so careful as other girls, he could be a little freer.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: And so, because I preferred to ride a mile with him to see something real that had happened, and tried to be useful instead of looking in shop windows in Main Street or promenading before the hotel-
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: And being ornamental.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Do you wish me to walk the rest of the way home?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: No,
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Then stop that kind of talk, right there!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I wish I was a man.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: And yet I used to go to fires in Sacramento when I was only ten years old. I saw the theatre burnt down. Nobody found fault with me then.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Object? I'd like to see them do it.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: What's the matter with your neck?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Let me. Do! I'm good at wounds. Come over here. No-stay there. I'll come over to you.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: It's nothing.
speaker: Cass Beard

utterance: Give me your flask.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: There, Now, button your coat over your chest, so, and don't take cold.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: What are you going to do with Hornsby?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: He only said,
speaker: Cass Beard
